Award.AwardTitle: A Curriculum for Security Assured Health Informatics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Information Sciences and Telecommunications (IST) programs at the School of Information Sciences (SIS) and the Health Information Management (HIM) program at the School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences (SHRS) in the University of Pittsburgh are working collaboratively to develop an integrated curriculum on Security Assured Healthcare Informatics (SAHI). The result is a novel curriculum that comprehensively integrates Health Informatics with Information Assurance (IA) and provide BS, MS and PhD level curriculum enhancements, and a development of integrated facility to foster educational and research activities in SAHI areas.The SAHI curriculum contributes to preparing high caliber professionals with comprehensive HIM and Information Assurance expertise that will help to address the critical and immediate need for a workforce trained to secure America's cyberspace. The project produces professionals to fill research and employment needs in the Western Pennsylvania region.

The SAHI curriculum consists of multiple graduate level SAHI tracks with components focused on Healthcare IT (HIT) within the IST programs, and a track focused on Healthcare Security and Privacy (HS&P) within the HIM program. BS curriculum is being modified to provide HIT S&P curriculum through course enhancements. A new SAHI track is being implemented by modifying the existing Networks and Security (N&S) track. Finally, the existing BSIS track is being extended to create a SAHI 4+1 FastTrack program that allows a student to earn BS and MS degrees in 5 years.

The work is being rigorously evaluated using both formative and summative effectiveness evaluations through extensive reviews and feedback collection. The Center for Instructional Development and Distance Education will create appropriate evaluation methods according to Kirkpatrick's four-level evaluation model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals: This project is a collaborative effort between the Department of Informatics and Networked Systems (DINS) in the School of Computing and Information (SCI), and the Department of Health Information Management (HIM) in the School of Health and Rehabilitation Sciences (SHRS) at the University of Pittsburgh to address the growing need for education in the area of healthcare security and privacy. With the growing dependence on the computing and information technologies that are rapidly evolving, healthcare sector is increasingly faced with secuirity and privacy challenges. In recent studies, healthcare cybersecurity and privacy issues have been shown to be in a critical condition. The project aims at developing educational programs and curricular modules to produce graduates who are well equiped with knowledge and skills to tackle the cyberscurity and privacy challenges in the healthcare sector. The major goals of the project are:

  • To develop Security Assured Health Informatics (SAHI) tracks with curriculum components focused on Healthcare IT (HIT) within DINS.
  • To develop a track focused on Healthcare Security and Privacy (HS&P) within the DHIM programs
  • To create a curriculum that fosters research and doctoral studies in SAHI areas.

Towards chieving athese goals, the project activities include adding relevant lecture modules in many courses in the DINS and the DHIM programs, creating new courses, teaching doctoral seminars to foster research in Healthcare Security and Privacy topics, creating lab exercises and carrying out various outreach activities. These also include making curriculum changes and updates to incorporate various tracks of studies and graduation paths.

Summary of Outcomes. The team members from the two schools have collaborated towards developing new tracks and curricular contents within their respective departments. Below, we summarize the outcomes within each school.

Major outcomes within the SRHS include the following:

  • Creation of a Security and Privacy track in the HIM’s graduate program.
  • A new program in Health Informatics (MSHI) has been developed that includes a graduate certificate in “Health Information Cybersecurity” 
  • Both fully online and the on-campus versions of the MSHI program including the associated "Health Information Cybersecurity" certificate is expected to be fully available in Spring 2020.
  • Several courses in HIM were modified/updated over the course of the project to establish the track/certificate in the MS HRS / MS HI program.
  • In collaboration with the SCI, a professional certificate in "Cybersecurity in Healthcare" is being designe; it is expected  to be finalized in 2020.

Major outcomes within the SCI include the following:

  • Established a sub-track in Health Informatics  (HI) within the MS Information Science (MSIS) degree's specialization in Security Assured Health Informatics (SAIS) - SAIS was certified for 5 CNSS standards and is currently certified for NSA's standard required for CAE/CAE-R designations. In addition to the HI sub-track, we also created sub-tracks in "Big Data Analytics" and "Database and Web Systems" within the SAIS specialization. 
  • Creation of an accelerated BS-X/MSIS program that allows a student pursuing BSIS or BSCS degree to finish both the BS and MSIS degrees within 5 years. This has been approved at the School level and is soon expected to be approved by the University,
  • Established the Certificate of Advanced Studies (CAS) in Health Informatics sub-focus within SAIS CAS -- this requires 15 credits of coursework focused on security/healthcare focused courses within the SAIS-HI sub-track mentioned above.
  • Course/modules/labs development: Developed new courses with healthcare S&P content; significantly redesigned some courses; offered Doctoral Seminar courses focused on Healthcare S&P, and incorporated healthcare S&P content in MSIS and BSIS courses. Courses that were enhanced with healthcare content are listed in our project website (http://www.sis.pitt.edu/lersais/research/sahi/course.html)  A total of 14 labs have been created (please see: http://www.sis.pitt.edu/lersais/research/sahi/lab.html) 
  • In the doctoral seminars and some advanced cybersecurity courses (including new ones), students were involved in research and development related Healthcare security and privacy projects. List of publications, some by PhD students supported by this grant, as well others have been uploaded (see list at: http://www.sis.pitt.edu/lersais/research/sahi/index.html#publication) Many students carried out healthcare security and privacy-related class projects.
  • Outreach and resources: PIs presented results of the project (both research and curriculum development related) in various conference and relevant forums, as well as mentored high school students on healthcare security and privacy related projects. The project website also includes a resource page that has a collection of research papers and links to various resources (tools, etc.) (see: http://www.sis.pitt.edu/lersais/research/sahi/resources.html.) 

 The project url is: http://www.sis.pitt.edu/lersais/research/sahi/index.html.
